column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

Cattle numbers remained similar with 310 yarded, quality varied, with the majority of the yarding secondary types with the odd pen of better quality cattle throughout the market. All the usual buying group were present, operating in a market with mixed results. Young cattle Grown steers and heifers slipped 10 to 25c/kg, limited numbers and quality a factor. Heavy cows sold to 4c better and the medium and lighter weights sold to 5c softer. Manufacturing dairy steers sold firm and the crossbreds sold to 15c cheaper. Heavy bulls slipped 10c and the younger lighter bulls gained 10c/kg.

Young cattle to the trade sold from 220c to 298c for the better quality and 110c to 230c/kg for the plainer secondary types. Grown Steers made from 225c to 280c, grown heifers sold 216c to 272c/kg. Manufacturing Beef steers made from 180c to 232c, and the dairy steers sold from 210c to 252c/kg.

Heavy cows sold from 210c to 258c/kg. Medium and light weight cows sold from 150c to 222c and Dairy cows made from 186c to 235c/kg. Heavy bulls sold from 185c to 240c and the lighter and young bulls from 140c to 250c/kg.

Market Reporter, Sheona Lamb
